image.altText: IVF Study

items.synopsis: Court documents allege scientists working for Monash IVF Group used embryos without consent, forged signatures and destroyed documents.

title.children: Pioneering IVF group accused of forging signatures and burning documents about genetic test

image.altText: Two men wearing green and red striped guernseys

items.synopsis: South Sydney premiership-winner and Indigenous All Stars representative Kyle Turner has died at the age of 31. Warning: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised that this article contains images and the name of a person who has died.

title.children: Souths NRL premiership-winner Kyle Turner dies aged 31

image.altText: The Hancock family in front of a small aircraft

items.synopsis: The portrait of a smiling family captured in 1976 gives little indication of the tensions that would later erupt between the generations — and 40 years later, the feud in the House of Hancock is still firmly in the national spotlight.

title.children: In 1976, Australia's richest family looked to be a happy unit. It's a different story 40 years later

image.altText: A giant cheese platter showcasing wedges of the companies cheese varieties.

items.synopsis: A boutique outfit from South Gippsland has been named "supreme artisan" on the international stage, cementing Australia's presence as a force to be reckoned with in the world of specialty cheese.

title.children: Australian cheesemakers snatch glory from France and Italy for the first time in 125 years

image.altText: Woman curled up with hands over abdomen

items.synopsis: In the short-term, inflammation is a sign your body is healing. But persistent levels of inflammation in blood and tissue — called "inflammaging" — is linked to disease, write Lauren Ball and Emily Burch.

title.children: Nine signs you have chronic inflammation in your body

image.altText: Sam Kerr stands in a huddle

items.synopsis: The Matildas are determined to take a bronze medal away from the Women's World Cup and coach Tony Gustavsson won't be handing out jerseys.

title.children: Matildas to be full strength for FIFA Women's World Cup third place play-off against Sweden

image.altText: Matildas team photo before the semi-finals

items.synopsis: Third place in the FIFA Women's World Cup is up for grabs tonight. Get up to speed with where the Matildas are playing and what happens after the tournament is over.

title.children: What time do the Matildas play tonight? And what comes after that?

image.altText: A photograph, taken from above, of dozens of umbrellas and sunlounges on a sandy beach.

items.synopsis: On this Greek island, going to many beaches now comes with a price tag — while locals there are fighting back, the concept of paying for a spot on the sand is starting to be seen Down Under.

title.children: 'People are very, very angry': When tourists swamped this island's beaches, locals decided to act

image.altText: A court sketch shows a woman in beige prison uniform sitting next to a man in a suit at a desk

items.synopsis: A court has found neonatal nurse Lucy Letby guilty of murdering the tiny, vulnerable people in her care. The parents of her victims now know who killed their children, but the question of why may forever remain unanswered.

title.children: When this hospital saw a spike in infant deaths, staff noticed unnerving similarities. One nurse was on shift every time

image.altText: Men walking through farm in dry mountain country in Afghanistan

items.synopsis: With the Taliban banning poppy production, this agriculture consultant from Darwin helps farmers in Afghanistan find viable and legal alternative crops.

title.children: Meet an Australian helping Afghan farmers find an alternative to opium poppies

image.altText: A man types numbers 365 into a phone calculator with cash and a wallet in the background

items.synopsis: Every time a currency trader or a share investor buys or sells, there's a reason behind it — and the millions of decisions made every day by investors tell a story. The story forming now is one of worry, writes David Taylor.

title.children: 'High risk' of Australian recession as China's property crisis deepens, dollar tumbles

image.altText: A large space craft rocketing through clouds in the sky, with flames coming from its engine exhausts

items.synopsis: India's space agency releases images of the Moon as its craft approaches the lunar south pole, a previously unexplored region where Russia is trying to land first.

title.children: India and Russia expected to land on Moon in coming days, amid race to find water on lunar south pole

image.altText: Composite photo of a woman in a blue medical shirt and a magpie with a makeshift boot on

items.synopsis: A Sunshine Coast vet is helping injured birds by creating shoes to assist their recovery, with her latest patient a magpie named after a popular brand of shoes.

title.children: Vet crafts special shoes to help injured magpie Birkenstock and other hurt birds find their feet again

image.altText: Morris Chang

items.synopsis: The best microchips in the world are made by TSMC. How did it become so important?

title.children: The world's most important company and why everyone wants control of it

image.altText: Behind-the-scenes on a film shoot

items.synopsis: Ever wanted to work on a TV or film set?  Employment in Australia's screen industry has jumped 37 per cent in recent years and crew members are wanted to work on productions. So what does it take to land a job?

title.children: As Australia's film industry booms, workers are wanted behind the scenes

image.altText: a man speaking at a mic in front of protestors holding signs

items.synopsis: Griffith MP Max Chandler-Mather says it is a "shot across the bow" for Labor, who this week announced it would reactivate its Help to Buy scheme.

title.children: Renters 'won't forgive' Labor, say Greens as hundreds protest at ALP conference

image.altText: PM Albanese waves to labor conference

items.synopsis: Labor rank and file return from the national conference with a call to action from the prime minister, as the government heads into its formal campaign for the Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: 'Mobilise': PM rallies troops as Labor ramps up Voice to Parliament campaign

image.altText: A man wearing glasses and a suit stands behind a lectern labelled "Working for Australia".

items.synopsis: Two years since the AUKUS deal was announced, the search for a sign that the government has made any progress on working out the details of the nuclear subs emits a sound as hollow as a sonar ping, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: Tensions surface as Albanese's ambitions become clear

image.altText: A bushwalker stands in button grass with eyes closed and smiles in the sun

items.synopsis: Rob Parsons is a social media influencer who shares his adventures in the Tasmanian wilderness. But he's just been threatened with legal action by the parks and wildlife service over what he says are outdated filming laws.

title.children: When this YouTube adventurer posted a video of his search for the Tasmanian tiger, he was threatened with legal action

image.altText: A man with a grey beard and wearing a broad-brimmed hat sits on a street and smiles

items.synopsis: A small Tasmanian town's only GP is quitting, citing burnout, an unsustainable workload and a lack of support from the government. Residents who credit him with saving lives fear what's going to become of local health services.

title.children: Frank was bleeding to death but a 'calm' GP saved his life. Now, the doctor is quitting over 'burn out'

image.altText: A woman standing near a fence next to an unfinished house.

items.synopsis: Analysts say the past 18 months have seen Australia's home construction industry weather one of the largest storms in decades. It's left countless families caught up in builder collapses teetering on the financial brink.

title.children: On the outskirts of Australian cities, families like Kalpana's are losing sleep as home dreams crumble

image.altText: In one image, Donald Trump speaks into a microphone. In another, Young Thug looks in the other direction.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump and rapper Young Thug may appear to have little in common. But both are being charged under the same law, in the same state, by the same prosecutor.

title.children: Young Thug faces the same charge as Donald Trump. And right now, he's sitting in a jail cell

image.altText: Taiwan's Vice President William Lai Ching-te waves amid a crowd of men in suits.

items.synopsis: China's military begins drills around Taiwan, saying it is a "serious warning" to separatist forces, in an angry and widely expected response to a visit of Vice President William Lai to the United States.

title.children: 'A serious warning': China launches drills around Taiwan in angry response to Vice President William Lai's US trip

image.altText: TigersBlues

items.synopsis: Jack Riewoldt and Trent Cotchin are helping lead the Tigers to victory in their final games, as Charlie Curnow is helping the Blues in a stunning recovery against the Suns. Follow our live AFL ScoreCentre for all the scores, stats and results.

title.children: AFL live: Riewoldt slots a goal in his final match, as Curnow leads stunning Blues comeback

image.altText: A Sydney Roosters NRLW player runs with the ball carried in right arm during a match in 2022.

items.synopsis: Gold Coast is on home turf as it faces the ladder-leading Sydney Roosters.Earlier, St George Illawarra edged out Wests Tigers in the final minute of play, and Cronulla ran in seven tries to beat North Queensland. Follow our NRLW ScoreCentre.

title.children: NRLW live: Titans host Roosters as Dragons, Sharks celebrate victories

image.altText: the outside of a ford car

items.synopsis: A technical glitch in an online auction led to a car raffle company securing a prized 1976 Ford Falcon Coupe for a "steal" before losing it in a re-run auction.

title.children: 'This is bad': How online auction glitch costs premature bidder classic 1976 Ford

image.altText: Premier close-up with index finger held up

items.synopsis: The State of Victoria has agreed to pay the Commonwealth Games parties $380 million in compensation after pulling out of the 2026 regional event.

title.children: Victoria to pay $380m compensation for cancelling 2026 Commonwealth Games

image.altText: Nicola Olyslagers leaps backwards over a bar

items.synopsis: Australia is sending its biggest ever field of athletes to the 2023 World Athletics Championships in Budapest, including two reigning champions and several other medal chances. Here's your run down ahead of competition starting Saturday night.

title.children: Aussies set to fly at World Athletics Championships

image.altText: a woman smiling and looking at the camera

items.synopsis: New data shows police are increasingly struggling to attend all triple-0 calls, especially those deemed to be less urgent.

title.children: A woman died this week after a delayed police response. New figures highlight a growing problem

image.altText: A woman with a shaved head smiles

items.synopsis: Breast cancer patients and advocates are decrying a lack of communication about mammograms for women in their 40s, as claims of pushback from services surface.

title.children: 'I just want this scan I'm entitled to': Giulia got pushback over a mammogram. She ended up having breast cancer

image.altText: A grey F16 fighter airplane takes off into a clear blue sky.

items.synopsis: The United States gives approval for the Netherlands and Denmark to deliver F-16s to Ukraine, officials in Washington and Europe say.

title.children: Ukraine will get F-16 fighter jets from the Dutch and Danes after the US agrees to allow transfers

image.altText: Michael Jackson, wearing a suit and tie, walks between the shoulders of two other men, one of whom holds an umbrella over him

items.synopsis: A US court revives lawsuits from two men, including an Australian, who allege Michael Jackson sexually abused them as boys.

title.children: Men who allege Michael Jackson sexually abused them as boys have lawsuits revived for jury trial

image.altText: Player no 14 jumps up to head a soccer ball with a grimace on her face

items.synopsis: Athletes who sustain concussions are usually quickly pulled from play and have teams of medical professionals overseeing their recoveries. Why aren't victims of domestic violence with brain injuries getting the same care and attention?

title.children: Why isn't the brain injury crisis in our homes causing as much concern as concussion in sport?
